stream_context.summary: Kaze spends the entire stream grey-boxing the new Ice-Castle level: planning slides, warp pipes, mirror-walls and star routes.  The focus is 100 % on making the platforming feel good before touching final art.
level: Ice Castle (un-named course inside Return to Yoshi’s Island)

development_findings.summary: Current sprint is ‘platforming first, visuals later’; once every route feels good Kaze will switch to lighting, shaders and decoration.
development_findings.quote: Our task for the day is to make the platforming good, and then after we made the platforming good we can make the visuals good.

development_findings.summary: Level pillars: lots of short slide segments, momentum jumps and optional speed-tech so difficulty scales with player bravery.
development_findings.quote: The game is as difficult as you are brave; you always have the option to take a safe route.

development_findings.summary: Star plan laid out: 1) central gauntlet star behind glass, 2) snowman-cave path star, 3) Big Raven boss after ice-block stair, 4) reds outside, 5) hidden 8-bit pipe in a jail cell, 6) Yoshi coin reward via secret warp.
Wind ‘window’ tiles used as both obstacle and helper; Kaze is tweaking velocity caps so long-jumps don’t launch Mario uncontrollably.
Technical attempt to make convincing ice shine with multi-texturing; Kaze’s solution works but doesn’t match collaborator Dan’s nicer prototype.
development_findings.quote: I couldn’t get the thing that he was trying to get to work.  The thing he did looked a lot better than what I have here.

development_findings.summary: Exploring mirror-wall concept: player wall-kicks between real wall and reflective surface showing ‘mirror Mario’.  Worry about performance (multiple Marios) and hall-of-mirrors artefacts on N64.
Camera is the hardest part; tight indoor rooms may force hard-coded corner cams or removal of rooms completely.
development_findings.quote: The camera will be an issue in tight indoor rooms like this.

development_findings.summary: Created swirling ‘void’ texture for bottomless pits; considering using it for boss attack where level flips and Mario falls into the sky.
Will stay within original 64 MB cartridge size and N64 hardware.  Considering future PC port or recompiler, but not a priority.
Performance tooling: intends to import Sauraen’s thread-time tracer to profile every frame.
Source code will be published only after release to avoid spoilers and rip-offs.
development_findings.quote: If I release it before then I dig my whole mod, so I don’t want that.

development_findings.summary: Brainstormed AI/FSR upscale idea: render at 160×120 then use upscaler on real hardware—filed as experimental.
development_findings.quote: Imagine you just have an option to turn DLSS on or off in your Mario 64 hack.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design philosophy: form follows function; every mechanic must fit the emotional theme of the area.
context_findings.quote: Making a game is all about designing a feeling that you want the player to have.

context_findings.summary: He avoids praising AI publicly due to fear of Twitter backlash.
context_findings.quote: I won’t say that anything AI is cool publicly because I think that I will literally be murdered on twitter.com.

context_findings.summary: Frugality is a personal trait: lived on €300/month, re-invests tool purchases, rarely spends on fun.
context_findings.quote: If my mom gives me $3 for food I’m going to keep the $3 and go hungry.

context_findings.summary: Tells story of ordering ‘chicken filet’ and receiving cheap frozen tenders—felt scammed, uses anecdote as chat engagement.
Streaming helps him focus but juggling chat, Twitch & YouTube windows is hectic; restream broke at start causing frustration.

biobak.summary: Suggested using a noise/alpha texture for bottomless pits, which Kaze implemented and liked.
Actively offered feedback on reflective walls and general visuals during stream.

key_stories.title: Ice-Castle Redesign Loop
key_stories.summary: Kaze realises an indoor passage ruins camera readability.  He deletes the room, reclaims space and re-routes the slide, instantly fixing both camera and flow.
key_stories.challenge: Tight corridor made camera unusable and confused players.
key_stories.process: Discussed alternatives with chat, decided to remove the entire corridor and widen the space, then re-compiled and live-tested.
key_stories.outcome: Platforming feels better; camera has clear sightlines; decision affirms ‘function first’ mantra.
key_stories.key_quote: This level is very much form-follows-function; I’d rather delete a room than keep bad camera.

key_stories.title: Failed Ice Shader vs Dan’s Prototype
key_stories.summary: Kaze experimented with multi-layer shining walls to look like ice but couldn’t match collaborator Dan’s superior result.
key_stories.challenge: Achieve convincing icy shine on N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Tried blending layers and moving highlights; consulted Dan; attempted his settings but couldn’t reproduce.
key_stories.outcome: Current version is acceptable but slated for revisit after platforming pass.
key_stories.key_quote: Unfortunately I couldn’t get the thing Dan did to work; his looked a lot better.
